channel.title: BBC Sport
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see https://www.bbc.co.uk/usingthebbc/terms-of-use/#15metadataandrssfeeds for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: How England's 'Golden Generation' describe the reasons why they failed
item.description: Tactical shortcomings, misguided managers or stellar opponents - why do England's so-called 'Golden Generation' think they failed to deliver success?

item.title: 'One of our best ever' - why Pickford is England's undisputed number one
item.description: BBC Sport looks in depth at the game of England goalkeeper Jordan Pickford, with the help of former Three Lions shot-stoppers Paul Robinson and Rob Green, and his former Toffees team-mates Wayne Rooney and Theo Walcott.

item.title: Uefa targets streamers in push for £4.3bn-a-year TV deals
item.description: The top European clubs could cash in on streaming rights as Uefa look to land around £4bn in their next TV deal.

item.title: 'Scotland hoping for all thriller and no killer in Greece showdown'
item.description: BBC Scotland's chief sportswriter Tom English sets the scene for Scotland's crucial World Cup qualifier with Greece.

item.title: Watford sack Pezzolano after 10 games and reappoint Gracia
item.description: Watford sack head coach Paulo Pezzolano after just 10 games in charge of the Championship club and replace him with former boss Javi Gracia.

item.title: Ronaldo is Bloomberg's first billionaire footballer
item.description: Portugal striker Cristiano Ronaldo is worth $1.4bn (£1.04bn), according to financial information and media firm Bloomberg.

item.title: Rabiot should respect employer, says Serie A boss
item.description: Serie A chief executive Luigi de Siervo says Adrien Rabiot should "respect his employer" after the AC Milan midfielder criticised plans for overseas league matches.

item.title: 'Being gay in men's football is a very toxic place'
item.description: Australian Josh Cavallo, who moved to England in July to join non-league Peterborough Sports, says football has got "mountains to do" to tackle homophobia.

item.title: Ferguson and Parrott fitness boost for Republic of Ireland
item.description: Republic of Ireland assistant head coach John O'Shea says strikers Evan Ferguson and Troy Parrott are both in contention to feature in Saturday's World Cup qualifier against Portugal.

item.title: Tarkowski signs new Everton deal and eyes Europe
item.description: Everton defender James Tarkowski says the club are targeting European football after signing a new two-year deal with the Toffees.

item.title: 'Slovakia qualifier NI's biggest game in years'
item.description: Northern Ireland's World Cup qualifier with Slovakia is their biggest game in years, says former international Stuart Dallas.

item.title: The day Wales beat England at Wembley
item.description: Wales face England on Thursday hoping to repeat the heroics of their 1977 predecessors.

item.title: 'We've got mountains to do' - Cavallo on homophobia in football
item.description: Josh Cavallo, who plays for Peterborough Sports in Australia and came out as gay in 2021, tells BBC Sport football has "mountains to do" in tackling homophobia in the game.

item.title: Injury woes made Stones think about retirement
item.description: Speaking to BBC Radio 5 Live, England and Manchester City defender John Stones says he considered retiring last season because of injury.

item.title: Sutton says calls for Postecoglou's sacking 'ridiculous'
item.description: Mark Chapman is joined by Chris Sutton and Rory Smith on the Monday Night Club to discuss Ange Postecoglou's results at Nottingham Forest, as Sutton calls fans "entitled" amid sacking calls.

item.title: I can raise my voice about injustice - Bellerin
item.description: Former Arsenal defender Hector Bellerin talks to Elizabeth Conway about his attempts to live a more sustainable life after being named global champion at the BBC Green Sport Awards.

item.title: 'Tough moments' after Saudi move for Henderson
item.description: England midfielder Jordan Henderson says he has had "tough moments" since leaving Liverpool for Saudi Arabia and could "have made different decisions".

item.title: England's Golden Generation were 'egotistical losers' - Gerrard
item.description: Former England captain Steven Gerrard says he sometimes "hated" being on international duty and blames a lack of success with the Three Lions on key players being "egotistical losers".

item.title: One match, over 5,000 gambling ads - is 'ban' really working?
item.description: Researchers say data showing the scale of gambling advertising in the Premier League proves self-regulation is failing.

item.title: Zirkzee wants to leave Man Utd - Wednesday's gossip
item.description: Joshua Zirkzee and Kobbie Mainoo want to leave Manchester United, Axel Disasi remains frozen out at Chelsea, Leeds want a winger, plus more.

item.title: Molumby 'angry' at being left out of last Republic of Ireland squad
item.description: Midfielder Jayson Molumby says he was "angry and disappointed" not be selected for Republic of Ireland during the previous international window.

item.title: 'The perfect signing' - Son's Messi-like impact in Los Angeles
item.description: After more than a decade at Tottenham Hotspur, BBC Sport looks at the impact "perfect signing" Son Heung-min is having at Los Angeles FC.

item.title: 'Vinicius smiling again but his future has never been more uncertain'
item.description: As Vinicius Junior enjoys his best start to a season at Real Madrid, European football expert Guillem Balague believes his future remains uncertain.

item.title: Injury made Stones 'think about retiring' last season
item.description: England and Manchester City defender John Stones is in England's squad for Thursday's friendly against Wales and next week's World Cup qualifier against Latvia.

item.title: Arsenal consider Wembley move to enable Emirates Stadium expansion
item.description: Arsenal hold internal discussions about expanding the capacity of Emirates Stadium, which currently sits just over 60,000.

item.title: Brown call up as Scotland boss savours 'challenge'
item.description: Head coach Melissa Andreatta names under-23 international Georgia Brown in the Scotland squad for this month's friendlies against Morocco and Switzerland.

item.title: Lockyer ready to play after 'long road' of cardiac arrest
item.description: Wales defender Tom Lockyer says he is ready to resume his football career after a lengthy recovery following a cardiac arrest.

item.title: 'I deeply hurt people by moving to Saudi Arabia'
item.description: In an interview with BBC Sport, Ashleigh Plumptre says she regrets losing the trust of some LGBT fans in women's football by moving to Saudi Arabia.

item.title: Can you name the teams from England 2-1 Wales at Euro 2016?
item.description: With England taking on Wales in a friendly at Wembley this week, can you name all 27 players who featured when the two countries met at Euro 2016?

item.title: Gerrard cites 'unfinished business' as Rangers wait
item.description: Rangers are awaiting confirmation over whether their former manager Steven Gerrard is interested in a return to Ibrox.

item.title: Baraclough has 'no bitterness' over NI sacking
item.description: As Northern Ireland prepare to host Slovakia in World Cup qualifying, former NI boss Ian Baraclough speaks to BBC Sport NI about his tenure.

item.title: Ex-Spain and Barcelona left-back Alba to retire
item.description: Former Spain and Barcelona left-back Jordi Alba will retire at the end of the current Major League Soccer season.

item.title: Fifa accuses Malaysia of faking foreign-born players' eligibility
item.description: The alleged forgery was done to comply with Fifa's 'grandfather rule' for foreign-born players.

item.title: 'Not over until it's over' - Parrott on World Cup hopes
item.description: Republic of Ireland striker Troy Parrott says the Irish squad retain belief that they can still qualify for next year's World Cup.

item.title: The footballer who cycles to work after being inspired by Wenger
item.description: Former Arsenal defender Hector Bellerin talks about his attempts to live a more sustainable life as he wins the BBC Green Sports Award.

item.title: Arsenal reward keeper Raya with improved deal
item.description: Arsenal reward goalkeeper David Raya with an improved contract to underline his status as one of Mikel Arteta's key players.

item.title: Records tumble as Donczew, 15, becomes Cardiff's youngest player
item.description: Records tumble in the EFL Trophy as Axel Donczew becomes Cardiff City's youngest player of all time.

item.title: Managerless Luton lose, Leeds thrashed in EFL Trophy
item.description: Cambridge United came from a goal down to beat managerless Luton Town 3-1 on a busy night in the Vertu Trophy.

item.title: Why is this the last October international break of its kind?
item.description: BBC Sport's Ask Me Anything team explain the major changes happening to football's international breaks starting in 2026.

item.title: Weymouth sack commentator for on-air board 'rant'
item.description: Non-league Weymouth sack club broadcaster Ben Ashelford over comments he made during a recent FA Trophy defeat by Wimborne Town.

item.title: How much would Tottenham Hotspur be worth?
item.description: BBC Sport's Ask Me Anything team explains how much Tottenham Hotspur is likely to be worth amid links with a future takeover.

item.title: Lammens' confidence grew on Man Utd debut - Schmeichel
item.description: Former Manchester United goalkeeper Peter Schmeichel praises 23-year-old Senne Lammens' performance for the Red Devils in their 2-0 victory over Sunderland.

item.title: Football or rugby? The new kick-off trend in the Premier League
item.description: Alex Scott, Steph Houghton and Chris Sutton discuss the increase in kick-offs that have been kicked straight out of play, or sent long into the final third, and why it's happening.

item.title: Rooney questions work ethic of 'lost' Salah
item.description: Wayne Rooney, Kelly Somers, Kae Kurd and John Gibbons from The Anfield Wrap discuss Liverpool's loss of form, and why their talisman Mohamed Salah looks "lost".

item.title: Kelly's stunner & Macario's backheel magic among WSL best goals
item.description: Strikes from Chloe Kelly, Mariona Caldentey and Anna Sandberg feature in this week's Women's Super League goals of the week.

item.title: 'He smelled blood' - Hart breaks down crucial Donnarumma save
item.description: Joe Hart breaks down a crucial save from Manchester City goalkeeper Gianluigi Donnarumma that denied Igor Thiago in their 1-0 win against Brentford.

item.title: Are 'exciting' Man Utd WSL title contenders?
item.description: The Women's Football Show pundits Fern Whelan & Nia Jones discuss whether Manchester United are Women's Super League title contenders.

item.title: 'They aren't talking about Isak any more' - is Woltemade proving his worth?
item.description: Match of the Day's Kelly Cates, Joe Hart and Danny Murphy discuss whether Nick Woltemade is proving he is worth the £69m Newcastle paid for him in the summer.

item.title: Watch the game that ended Martin's Rangers tenure
item.description: Watch highlights of what proved to be Russell Martin's final game as Rangers head coach, the 1-1 draw at Falkirk. (Available to UK users only)

item.title: Tuchel having eyes on Grealish 'inevitable' - Murphy
item.description: Match of the Day's Danny Murphy says England manager Thomas Tuchel having his eyes on Jack Grealish for international duty is "inevitable" if he keeps up his strong performances for Everton.

item.title: Two stunning strikes help Villa extend West Ham's losing start
item.description: Aston Villa claim their first WSL win of the season with two impressive goals and inflict a seventh successive league loss on West Ham.

item.title: 'You've got to give a manager time' - Hart on life under Postecoglou
item.description: Match of the Day's Joe Hart talks about his experience playing under Ange Postecoglou at Celtic to explain why he should be given more time at Nottingham Forest.

item.title: 'Gobby troublemaker to meticulous coach' - Bellamy's evolution
item.description: Craig Bellamy has evolved from a spiky, controversial player to a deep-thinking coach of Wales, as those who know him best tell BBC Sport.

item.title: The younger Mbappe emerging from his brother's shadow
item.description: Being the brother of a football superstar is not easy. But Ethan Mbappe is aiming to emerge from the shadows and make a name for himself.

item.title: What to look out for as Women's Champions League returns
item.description: The Women's Champions League league phase is about to begin - and BBC Sport takes a look at what to expect from the new format.

item.title: Why Liverpool aren't getting the best from Wirtz yet
item.description: A deep dive into Florian Wirtz's performances for Liverpool so far and why he isn't yet at his best.

item.title: Arsenal lead set-piece trend as NFL tactics spread
item.description: Umir Irfan looks at how football teams are using blocking moves at set-pieces in a similar way to how NFL players block their opponents.

item.title: Transfers - September to December 2025
item.description: Check out the significant signings and departures in the Premier League, Scottish Premiership, EFL and Women's Super League.

item.title: Manager ins and outs - 2025-26 season
item.description: BBC Sport tracks all the manager ins and outs in the Premier League, Scottish Premiership, Women's Super League, English Football League and National League.

item.title: What is '007' in football?
item.description: Our Ask Me Anything Team look at what the tagline of '007' means and where the taunt came from.

item.title: Why did Man Utd's Yoro kick off a match in France?
item.description: BBC Sport's Ask Me Anything team explains why Manchester United's Leny Yoro kicked off a match in France.

item.title: What are penalty retake rules after Roma penalty drama?
item.description: BBC Sport's Ask Me Anything team explains the rules on penalty retakes after Roma took the same penalty three times against Lille in the Europa League

item.title: Why are Kazakhstan part of Uefa?
item.description: BBC Sport's Ask Me Anything team explains why Kazakhstan are part of Uefa.

item.title: Why are some football shin pads so small?
item.description: Our Ask Me Anything team explore why some football shin pads are so small, and what the laws are around wearing them.

item.title: Why was Calafiori banned from using a towel for throw-ins?
item.description: Arsenal's Riccardo Calafiori was stopped from drying the ball with a towel against Newcastle - but why did that happen?

item.title: Is the Premier League getting younger?
item.description: BBC Sport's Ask Me Anything looks into why increasing number of teenagers and young players are playing in the Premier League this season.

item.title: Dyche not interested in Rangers job - gossip
item.description: One manager seemingly out of the running for Rangers' vacancy as another surprise name comes to the fore.

item.title: Celtic board 'remains detached', says fan group after meeting
item.description: Monday's meeting between supporters' representatives and some members of the Celtic board "produced no tangible outcomes", say the Celtic Fans Collective.

item.title: Injured Yamal out of Spain World Cup qualifiers
item.description: Barcelona winger Lamine Yamal is out for "two to three weeks" with a groin injury and misses Spain's World Cup qualifying matches against Georgia and Bulgaria.

item.title: 'Masters of their own downfall' - is Arsenal form just a blip?
item.description: Arsenal are now without a win in their past four games following a 2-1 defeat by Lyon in the Women's Champions League.

item.title: Can you name every team in 2025-26 Women's Champions League?
item.description: For this week's big Tuesday quiz we want you to name every team in the Women's Champions League league phase in seven minutes.

item.title: From farming village to Liverpool icon - the Salah story
item.description: BBC Sport visits Egypt to discover what Mohamed Salah means to the people of the football-mad country, and how a small boy from humble beginnings became a national icon.

item.title: Napoli 'smell blood' & target Premier League's discarded stars
item.description: After Scott McTominay was a hit, Napoli went back to the Premier League for Kevin de Bruyne, could more players follow them to Serie A?

item.title: How does Daniel Levy run Tottenham - and would he ever leave?
item.description: With Tottenham struggling on the pitch and chairman Daniel Levy facing criticism from fans, BBC Sport looks at how the club is run and what the future might hold.

item.title: When River Plate icon Diaz took over fourth-tier Oxford
item.description: Twenty years on from Ramon Diaz's surprising appointment at Oxford United, BBC Sport looks at what happened and how it went.

item.title: East meets west London - the mentor who changed Chelsea
item.description: Vinay Menon knew nothing about football when he went for a meeting at a west London mansion in 2009. A few weeks later he was in the heart of the Chelsea dressing room.

item.title: The air crash and the underdogs - a triumph for a lost generation
item.description: Nineteen years and 10 miles separated Zambia's football team from a lost, golden generation on a fateful night in Libreville.

item.title: The rise and fall of North Korea - the sleeping giant of women's football
item.description: North Korea lags behind most of the rest of the world in several areas. But the hermit state has had an outsized impact on international women's football.
